pathogens.name: Salmonella
pathogens.definition: Gram-negative rods causing acute foodborne gastroenteritis and invasive infection. Non-typhoidal Salmonella is a leading cause of foodborne illness worldwide.

reservoir.notes: Widely distributed in animals and environment. Can survive in dry conditions for extended periods.

routes: Contaminated food (especially undercooked poultry and eggs)
transmission.notes: Most common via undercooked poultry and eggs. Cross-contamination during food preparation is a major risk.

incubationPeriod.infectiousPeriod: Duration of illness + several weeks in stool (can be months in infants)
incubationPeriod.seasonality: Summer peak (warmer months favor bacterial growth)
incubationPeriod.geographic: Worldwide, higher incidence in developing countries with poor sanitation

riskFactors: Sickle cell disease (risk of invasive infection)

caseDefinition.suspected: Acute diarrhea (≥3 loose stools/24h) + fever + abdominal pain + food exposure history within 72 hours
caseDefinition.confirmed: Isolation of Salmonella from stool, blood, or other clinical specimen by culture or PCR

diagnosis: Stool culture (gold standard, 24-48 hours)
Blood culture (if systemic infection suspected)
PCR/molecular testing (rapid, 2-4 hours)
Serotyping for outbreak investigation (PFGE, WGS)
pathogens.treatment: Supportive care (oral or IV hydration) is primary treatment. Antibiotics for severe cases or high-risk patients: ciprofloxacin, azithromycin, ceftriaxone. Avoid antibiotics in uncomplicated cases (prolongs carriage and increases resistance). Antimotility agents (loperamide) are contraindicated.

infectionControl.precautions: Standard + Contact Precautions (for incontinent or diapered patients)
infectionControl.screening: Not routinely recommended. Consider for outbreak investigation.
infectionControl.cohorting: Cohort cases during outbreak. Separate from immunocompromised patients.
infectionControl.sourceControl: Identify and remove contaminated food source. Trace back to supplier.
infectionControl.environmental: Enhanced cleaning of bathrooms, food prep areas, and patient rooms. Use EPA-approved disinfectants.
infectionControl.staffEducation: Hand hygiene (most important), food safety, proper PPE use, avoid work when symptomatic

outbreakTriggers: ≥2 epidemiologically linked cases within 4 weeks
Common food source or event identified
Increase above baseline rate for the facility/community
Same serotype identified in multiple cases (molecular typing)
reportingCommunication: Notify local health department immediately (reportable disease)
Report to CDC via NORS (National Outbreak Reporting System)
Alert food safety authorities (FDA, USDA) if foodborne source
Communicate with affected facilities, restaurants, or communities
Public health alert if widespread or ongoing outbreak
Coordinate with infection control and hospital leadership
prevention: Proper food handling and storage (refrigerate <4°C)
Cook poultry to internal temperature 165°F (74°C)
Avoid raw or undercooked eggs and unpasteurized milk
Hand hygiene after handling animals, raw food, or using bathroom
Separate raw and cooked foods (prevent cross-contamination)
Food handler education and health screening
Exclude symptomatic food handlers from work

pathogens.name: Shigella
pathogens.definition: Gram-negative rod, highly infectious, causes dysentery; both food- and waterborne. Shigella is one of the most contagious bacterial pathogens, requiring as few as 10-100 organisms to cause infection.

reservoir.notes: Humans are the primary reservoir. No animal reservoir. Highly infectious with low infectious dose.

transmission.notes: Highly contagious with person-to-person transmission being most common, especially in daycare centers and institutions.

incubationPeriod.infectiousPeriod: During illness and up to 1 week after diarrhea resolves (can be longer in children)
incubationPeriod.seasonality: Year-round, with peaks in summer and early fall
incubationPeriod.geographic: Worldwide, higher incidence in areas with poor sanitation and crowded conditions

riskFactors: Men who have sex with men (MSM)

caseDefinition.suspected: Patient with acute diarrhea (especially bloody) + abdominal cramps + fever + epidemiologic link (daycare, institution, outbreak)
caseDefinition.confirmed: Laboratory confirmation: positive stool culture or PCR for Shigella species

diagnosis: Stool culture (gold standard)
PCR for Shigella species
Fecal leukocytes (often present)
Antimicrobial susceptibility testing (increasing resistance)
pathogens.treatment: Supportive care with oral or IV rehydration. Antibiotics for severe cases or high-risk patients: azithromycin (first-line), ciprofloxacin (if susceptible), or ceftriaxone. Avoid antimotility agents (loperamide).

infectionControl.precautions: Contact Precautions (gloves + gown) until diarrhea resolves
infectionControl.screening: Not routinely recommended; test symptomatic individuals
infectionControl.cohorting: Cohort cases during outbreaks, especially in daycare and institutional settings
infectionControl.sourceControl: Exclude sick food handlers and daycare workers until symptom-free for 24-48 hours and negative stool cultures (if required)
infectionControl.environmental: Enhanced cleaning and disinfection of bathrooms, high-touch surfaces, and shared equipment with EPA-approved disinfectants
infectionControl.staffEducation: Hand hygiene with soap and water (alcohol less effective), proper diaper changing procedures, contact precautions, exclusion policies

outbreakTriggers: ≥2 epidemiologically linked cases in same setting (daycare, institution, household)
Any single case in high-risk group (daycare, food handler, healthcare worker)
Cluster above baseline rate in community or facility
Detection of unusual antimicrobial resistance pattern
reportingCommunication: Notify public health within 24 hours of suspected outbreak
Start outbreak investigation and contact tracing immediately
Coordinate with daycare/institutional leadership for case finding
Implement control measures promptly (exclusion, hygiene education)
Update stakeholders as outbreak evolves
Document all cases and interventions
prevention: Hand hygiene with soap and water (most critical)
Safe water and sanitation infrastructure
Proper food handling and preparation
Exclusion of ill food handlers and daycare workers
Sanitation training in high-risk settings
Fly control measures
Travel health education for endemic areas

pathogens.name: Campylobacter jejuni
pathogens.definition: Curved Gram-negative rod, most common cause of bacterial gastroenteritis globally. Campylobacter is a leading cause of foodborne diarrheal illness worldwide, often associated with poultry consumption.

reservoir.notes: Poultry is the most common source. Campylobacter colonizes the intestinal tract of birds without causing illness.

transmission.notes: Most infections are sporadic rather than outbreak-associated. Cross-contamination during poultry preparation is a major risk.

incubationPeriod.infectiousPeriod: Contagious while excreting bacteria (several days to weeks, typically 2-3 weeks without treatment)
incubationPeriod.seasonality: Peak in late spring and summer months
incubationPeriod.geographic: Worldwide, with higher incidence in developed countries due to better surveillance

riskFactors: Drinking unpasteurized milk or untreated water
Inadequate cooking and food handling practices
Contact with farm animals or pets with diarrhea

caseDefinition.suspected: Patient with acute diarrhea (often bloody) + abdominal cramps + fever + exposure to undercooked poultry or untreated water
caseDefinition.confirmed: Laboratory confirmation: positive stool culture (requires microaerophilic conditions) or PCR for Campylobacter species

diagnosis: Stool culture (requires special microaerophilic conditions: 5% O2, 10% CO2, 85% N2)
PCR for Campylobacter species (increasingly used)
Gram stain (characteristic curved or S-shaped rods)
Antimicrobial susceptibility testing (increasing fluoroquinolone resistance)
pathogens.treatment: Supportive care with oral or IV rehydration (most cases self-limited). Antibiotics for severe cases or high-risk patients: azithromycin (first-line) or erythromycin. Fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin) if susceptible, but resistance is increasing.

infectionControl.precautions: Contact Precautions for hospitalized patients with diarrhea
infectionControl.screening: Not routinely recommended; test symptomatic individuals
infectionControl.cohorting: Cohort cases during outbreaks if needed
infectionControl.sourceControl: Exclude sick food handlers until symptom-free for 24 hours; identify and eliminate contaminated food or water sources
infectionControl.environmental: Enhanced cleaning and disinfection of food preparation areas, bathrooms, and high-touch surfaces
infectionControl.staffEducation: Hand hygiene, proper poultry handling and cooking (internal temp 165°F/74°C), cross-contamination prevention, water safety

outbreakTriggers: ≥2-3 epidemiologically linked cases in same exposure group (e.g., restaurant, event)
Sudden outbreak or cluster above baseline
Common source identified (contaminated food or water)
Unusual increase in cases in community
reportingCommunication: Prompt public health notification within 24 hours of suspected outbreak
Investigation and risk communication to affected populations
Coordinate with food safety authorities if foodborne source suspected
Trace back to identify contaminated products or water sources
Update stakeholders and implement control measures
Public education on safe food handling
prevention: Safe poultry preparation: cook to 165°F (74°C), avoid cross-contamination
Water quality monitoring and treatment
Pasteurization of milk and dairy products
Hand hygiene after handling raw poultry or animals
Food handler education and training
Public health outreach on food safety
Biosecurity measures on poultry farms

pathogens.name: E. coli (O157:H7 & STEC)
pathogens.scientificName: Escherichia coli O157:H7 and other Shiga toxin-producing E. coli (STEC)
pathogens.definition: Shiga toxin-producing E. coli causing bloody diarrhea and hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS); both food- and waterborne. STEC produces Shiga toxins (Stx1, Stx2) that cause severe intestinal and systemic complications.

reservoir.notes: Cattle are the primary reservoir. E. coli O157:H7 is the most common STEC serotype, but non-O157 STEC are increasingly recognized.

routes: Raw or undercooked produce (lettuce, spinach, sprouts)
Direct contact with infected animals (petting zoos, farms)
transmission.notes: Very low infectious dose (10-100 organisms). Cross-contamination during food preparation is a major risk.

incubationPeriod.infectiousPeriod: Infectious during illness and for days to weeks after diarrhea resolves (especially in children)
incubationPeriod.geographic: Worldwide, with higher incidence in developed countries with better surveillance

riskFactors: Young children (<5 years) - highest risk for HUS
Eating raw produce or unpasteurized products
Contact with farm animals or petting zoos

complications: Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) - 5-10% of cases, especially children
Acute kidney injury and renal failure

caseDefinition.suspected: Patient with bloody diarrhea + severe abdominal cramps + exposure to undercooked beef, raw produce, or contaminated water; any case of HUS in a child
caseDefinition.confirmed: Laboratory confirmation: stool culture positive for E. coli O157:H7 or other STEC, or detection of Shiga toxins (Stx1, Stx2) by PCR or immunoassay

diagnosis: Stool culture for E. coli O157:H7 (sorbitol-MacConkey agar)
PCR for Shiga toxin genes (stx1, stx2) - detects all STEC
Enzyme immunoassay (EIA) for Shiga toxins
Serotyping and molecular subtyping (PFGE, WGS) for outbreak investigation
Complete blood count and renal function tests if HUS suspected
pathogens.treatment: Supportive care with careful fluid and electrolyte management. AVOID antibiotics (may increase risk of HUS by releasing more toxins). ICU care for HUS: dialysis, blood transfusions, plasma exchange. Avoid antimotility agents (loperamide).

infectionControl.precautions: Contact Precautions for hospitalized patients with diarrhea
infectionControl.screening: Not routinely recommended; test all patients with bloody diarrhea
infectionControl.cohorting: Cohort cases during outbreaks, especially in daycare settings
infectionControl.sourceControl: Immediate identification and removal of contaminated food or water source; exclude sick food handlers and daycare workers
infectionControl.environmental: Enhanced cleaning and disinfection of bathrooms, high-touch surfaces, and food preparation areas
infectionControl.staffEducation: Hand hygiene, proper cooking of ground beef (160°F/71°C), produce washing, cross-contamination prevention, recognition of HUS

outbreakTriggers: ≥2-3 epidemiologically linked cases with same exposure
Any case of HUS in a child (triggers immediate investigation)
Unusual cluster or increase above baseline
Common source identified (contaminated food or water)
reportingCommunication: Rapid reporting within 24 hours of suspected case or outbreak
Escalate immediately if HUS or death occurs
Coordinate with food safety and environmental health authorities
Product recall if contaminated food identified
Public health alerts and media communication
Contact tracing and case finding
prevention: Cook ground beef to 160°F (71°C) - use meat thermometer
Wash produce thoroughly under running water
Avoid unpasteurized milk, juice, and cider
Prevent cross-contamination (separate cutting boards for meat and produce)
Hand hygiene after handling raw meat or animals
Supervise children at petting zoos (hand washing)
Water quality monitoring and treatment
Public education on food safety

pathogens.name: Listeria monocytogenes
pathogens.definition: Gram-positive rod causing outbreaks via ready-to-eat foods, with very high risk in pregnancy, elderly, and immunocompromised. Listeria is unique among foodborne pathogens in its ability to grow at refrigeration temperatures.

reservoir.notes: Listeria is ubiquitous in the environment and can persist in food processing facilities for years. Can grow at refrigeration temperatures (4°C).

routes: Contaminated ready-to-eat foods (deli meats, hot dogs, soft cheeses)
Refrigerated foods stored for extended periods
Vertical transmission (mother to fetus during pregnancy)
transmission.notes: Most infections are foodborne. Listeria can grow at refrigeration temperatures, making refrigerated ready-to-eat foods a major risk.

incubationPeriod.range: Days to 70 days (average 3 weeks for invasive disease; 24 hours for gastroenteritis)
incubationPeriod.infectiousPeriod: Infectious while colonized (can be prolonged); vertical transmission during pregnancy
incubationPeriod.geographic: Worldwide, with higher incidence in developed countries due to consumption of ready-to-eat foods

riskFactors: Pregnancy (20 times higher risk; can cause miscarriage, stillbirth, neonatal infection)
Consumption of high-risk foods (deli meats, soft cheeses, smoked seafood)

symptoms: Febrile gastroenteritis (mild form in healthy adults)

caseDefinition.suspected: High-risk patient (pregnant, elderly, immunocompromised) with fever + compatible illness (meningitis, sepsis, gastroenteritis) + consumption of high-risk foods
caseDefinition.confirmed: Laboratory confirmation: culture-positive for L. monocytogenes from normally sterile site (blood, CSF) or stool, or PCR detection

diagnosis: Culture from blood, CSF, or other sterile sites (gold standard)
Stool culture (for gastroenteritis)
PCR for Listeria species
Gram stain (small Gram-positive rods)
Serotyping and molecular subtyping (PFGE, WGS) for outbreak investigation
pathogens.treatment: Ampicillin or penicillin G ± gentamicin (synergistic combination) for invasive disease. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for penicillin-allergic patients. Duration: 2-6 weeks depending on site of infection. Supportive care for gastroenteritis.

infectionControl.precautions: Standard Precautions (no special isolation needed for most cases); Contact Precautions for neonates with invasive disease
infectionControl.screening: Not routinely recommended; test high-risk patients with compatible illness
infectionControl.cohorting: Not typically needed; isolate neonates with invasive disease
infectionControl.sourceControl: Product recall and removal from market; exclude at-risk individuals from consuming high-risk foods during outbreaks
infectionControl.environmental: Enhanced cleaning and sanitation of food processing facilities; environmental sampling to identify contamination sources
infectionControl.staffEducation: Food safety education for high-risk populations (pregnant women, elderly, immunocompromised), proper food storage and handling, recognition of high-risk foods

outbreakTriggers: Any single confirmed case in high-risk group (pregnant woman, neonate) triggers investigation
≥2 cases with same molecular subtype (PFGE, WGS)
Cluster of cases with common food exposure
Detection of Listeria in food products or processing environment
reportingCommunication: Urgent notification to public health within 2-24 hours of confirmed case
Alert food safety authorities immediately
Coordinate product recall if contaminated food identified
Public health alerts to high-risk populations
Molecular subtyping (PFGE, WGS) to link cases
Trace-back investigation to identify contaminated products
prevention: Food safety education for high-risk populations (avoid deli meats, soft cheeses, smoked seafood unless heated)
Cold chain monitoring (refrigeration <4°C slows but does not stop growth)
Pasteurization of milk and dairy products
Proper food handling and storage
Environmental monitoring in food processing facilities
Pregnant women should avoid high-risk foods
Reheat ready-to-eat foods to steaming hot (165°F/74°C) before consumption

pathogens.name: Vibrio cholerae
pathogens.definition: Curved Gram-negative rod causing cholera—profuse watery diarrhea and severe dehydration. Cholera is a life-threatening diarrheal disease caused by toxigenic V. cholerae O1 or O139, primarily transmitted through contaminated water.

reservoir.notes: V. cholerae is endemic in many developing countries with poor water and sanitation infrastructure. Can survive in aquatic environments.

routes: Eating contaminated food (especially raw or undercooked seafood)
Eating food washed or prepared with contaminated water
transmission.notes: Waterborne transmission is the primary route. Outbreaks often occur after natural disasters or in areas with poor sanitation.

incubationPeriod.infectiousPeriod: Infectious while diarrhea persists (typically 1-10 days; can be longer in carriers)
incubationPeriod.seasonality: Seasonal peaks in endemic areas (monsoon season, warm months)
incubationPeriod.geographic: Endemic in parts of Africa, South Asia, and Latin America; outbreaks in areas with poor sanitation or after disasters

riskFactors: Living in or traveling to cholera-endemic areas
Poor sanitation and lack of clean water
Consumption of raw or undercooked seafood
Natural disasters (floods, earthquakes) disrupting water systems
Achlorhydria (low stomach acid, PPI use) - increases susceptibility

symptoms: Rapid heart rate and low blood pressure
Dry mucous membranes and decreased skin turgor
complications: Death (within hours if untreated; mortality <1% with proper treatment)

caseDefinition.suspected: Patient ≥5 years with acute watery diarrhea + severe dehydration or death, in cholera-endemic area or during outbreak; OR patient ≥2 years with acute watery diarrhea in area with cholera outbreak
caseDefinition.confirmed: Laboratory detection required: stool culture positive for toxigenic V. cholerae O1 or O139, or rapid diagnostic test (RDT) positive

diagnosis: Stool culture on selective media (TCBS agar - thiosulfate-citrate-bile salts-sucrose)
Rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs) - Crystal VC, cholera dipstick
Dark-field microscopy (characteristic darting motility)
Serotyping (O1 or O139) and biotyping (classical or El Tor)
PCR for cholera toxin genes (ctxA, ctxB)
pathogens.treatment: Oral rehydration solution (ORS) for mild-moderate dehydration. IV rehydration (Ringer's lactate) for severe dehydration. Antibiotics shorten duration and reduce transmission: doxycycline (first-line), azithromycin, or ciprofloxacin. Zinc supplementation for children.

infectionControl.precautions: Contact Precautions (gloves + gown) for hospitalized patients; Standard Precautions with good hand hygiene in community settings
infectionControl.screening: Not routinely recommended; test symptomatic individuals in endemic areas or during outbreaks
infectionControl.cohorting: Cohort cases during outbreaks; establish cholera treatment centers (CTCs) for large outbreaks
infectionControl.sourceControl: Water chlorination and treatment; identify and eliminate contaminated water sources; safe disposal of fecal waste
infectionControl.environmental: Enhanced sanitation and hygiene; chlorination of water supplies; safe food preparation; fly control
infectionControl.staffEducation: Hand hygiene with soap and water, safe water handling, proper use of ORS, recognition of severe dehydration, contact precautions

outbreakTriggers: Any single confirmed case of toxigenic V. cholerae O1 or O139 in non-endemic area
≥2 linked cases in community or facility
Sudden increase in acute watery diarrhea cases
Detection of V. cholerae in water sources
reportingCommunication: Immediate health authority alert (within 24 hours or sooner)
Implement outbreak response and water testing protocols
Coordinate with WASH (water, sanitation, hygiene) teams
Establish cholera treatment centers if needed
Public health alerts and community education
International notification if required (IHR - International Health Regulations)
prevention: Clean water supply and treatment (chlorination, boiling)
Improved sanitation infrastructure (latrines, sewage systems)
Hand hygiene campaigns (soap and water)
Safe food preparation (cook food thoroughly, avoid raw seafood)
Oral cholera vaccine (OCV) for high-risk populations and outbreak response
Health education in endemic areas
WASH interventions in refugee camps and disaster settings

pathogens.name: Legionella pneumophila
pathogens.definition: Gram-negative bacillus causing Legionnaires' disease (severe pneumonia) via contaminated water aerosols. Legionella is an environmental bacterium that thrives in warm water systems and causes outbreaks through inhalation of contaminated aerosols.

primary: Water systems (cooling towers, hot water tanks, plumbing)
reservoir.notes: Legionella thrives in warm water (25-45°C) and biofilms. Cooling towers are the most common source of community outbreaks.

routes: Inhalation of aerosols from cooling towers
Inhalation of aerosols from showers, faucets, or misters
Inhalation of aerosols from hot tubs, spas, or fountains
transmission.notes: Transmission is exclusively through inhalation of contaminated aerosols. Person-to-person transmission is extremely rare (only 2 documented cases).

incubationPeriod.range: 2-10 days (typically 5-6 days for Legionnaires' disease; 1-2 days for Pontiac fever)
incubationPeriod.infectiousPeriod: Person-to-person transmission is extremely rare; not considered contagious
incubationPeriod.seasonality: Peak in summer and early fall (warmer water temperatures favor growth)
incubationPeriod.geographic: Worldwide, with higher incidence in developed countries due to complex water systems and better surveillance

riskFactors: Recent travel or hospitalization (exposure to contaminated water systems)

symptoms: Shortness of breath and chest pain
Gastrointestinal symptoms (diarrhea, nausea, vomiting) - 50% of cases
complications: Death (10-15% mortality; up to 40% in nosocomial cases)
Pontiac fever (mild, self-limited flu-like illness without pneumonia)

caseDefinition.suspected: Patient with pneumonia + fever + risk factors (age >50, smoking, chronic lung disease) + exposure to potential water source (cooling tower, hotel, hospital)
caseDefinition.confirmed: Laboratory confirmation: positive urinary antigen test (detects L. pneumophila serogroup 1 only), culture from respiratory specimen, or PCR

diagnosis: Urinary antigen test (rapid, detects L. pneumophila serogroup 1 - most common)
Culture from respiratory specimen (sputum, BAL) on selective media (BCYE agar)
PCR for Legionella species (detects all species and serogroups)
Serology (antibody testing) - requires paired sera, retrospective diagnosis
Chest X-ray or CT (patchy infiltrates, often multilobar)
pathogens.treatment: Fluoroquinolones (levofloxacin, moxifloxacin - first-line) or macrolides (azithromycin). Duration: 7-10 days for immunocompetent, 14-21 days for immunocompromised. Supportive care: oxygen, mechanical ventilation if needed. Do NOT use beta-lactams (ineffective).

infectionControl.precautions: Standard Precautions (no isolation needed; person-to-person transmission extremely rare)
infectionControl.sourceControl: Identify and remediate contaminated water sources; water system disinfection (thermal shock, hyperchlorination, copper-silver ionization)
infectionControl.environmental: Water system monitoring and disinfection; cooling tower maintenance and cleaning; hot water temperature >60°C, cold water <20°C; regular water testing for Legionella
infectionControl.staffEducation: Recognition of Legionnaires' disease, water safety plans, building maintenance, environmental sampling, respiratory protection during remediation

outbreakTriggers: ≥2 cases linked to same water source (building, hotel, hospital, cooling tower)
Clustering of cases in time or place
Detection of Legionella in environmental water samples
Single case in healthcare facility (triggers investigation)
reportingCommunication: Rapid reporting to public health and environmental health authorities
Environmental assessment and water testing immediately
Multi-disciplinary outbreak response (clinical, environmental, engineering)
Notify building management and occupants
Coordinate remediation efforts
Public health alerts if community outbreak
prevention: Water safety plans and management programs
Regular cooling tower maintenance, cleaning, and disinfection
Building water system maintenance (temperature control, flushing)
Environmental monitoring (water testing for Legionella)
Hot water temperature >60°C at point of use
Cold water temperature <20°C
Staff and building manager education
Awareness campaigns for high-risk populations
